remixed_from.author: ftobler
remixed_from.title: Mini Drill Press for PCB Drill

title: Adjustable bracket plus feet for Mini Drill Press for PCB Drill by ftobler

description.text:
I have originally made this slight change to Mini Drill Press for PCB Drill
by ftobler, because to fit my drill which was of 35mm diameter. But I have included the FreeCAD design of the bracket that I recreated using booleans and thus can be parameterized by changing the original shape sizes and recreating the solids that correspond to each subtraction-addition then move on to the next subtraction-addition. That way I believe one can create any bracket diameter they need. Also any other dimension can be changed in the FreeCAD files because the whole design comes down to primitive objects. All objects and transitions are included and named to be easily identified and changed.

As a footnote I forgot to drill holes in the bracket opening but I realized that simply by making the diameter 1mm less then that of the drill and given that the bracket has room for movement due to its opening, the bolt is not really needed to hold the bracket in place.

I also added four feet to my wooden base because I decided to drill through the base and put nuts on both sides of the base to hold the body more rigidly. This created the need to elevate the base to make room for the nuts and be flush. The flanges I created as feet are simply nailed on the base because they have a 1mm hole in their center.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

80%

Notes:

I printed the design with a much higher resolution and infill to make it sturdier, though I do not have enough experience to say for sure that this will work. So, take these print settings as simple guidelines and apply your experience to determine if they are correct or not.

This is a slight change on the mini drill press to fit a larger drill It also has some modifications and includes the freecad files of the bracket because as I saw there where many people that wanted to use the drill press but had a different drill. With the freecad design one can change any dimension of the bracket and thus create a bracket for their own drill.

This is a useful tool for your bench I printed this thing to use it as a tool and in fact it works like a charm. You can drill very small holes without endangering to break the drill's tip so easily, as you could by using the drill by hand.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Plotter for Wanhao DI3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi everybody.

This is my first thing that I upload to Thingiverse.

In the sección "How to use?" I describe the method that I use for convert my Wanhao DI3 on a pen-plotter, and the instructions to make the code with cura.

You can glue the nut to the printed model.

I attach the file "Texto.ini" that is the profile settings that i use on Cura for plotting.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

STEPS

1.- First install the "plotter" on your Wanhao DI3, you must remove the cooling fan. Dont put the pen in this step.

2.- Disconnect the cooling fan and the stepper motor of the extruder.

3.- Turn on the printer and send to home on quick settings. NOTE: You should not turn off the printer from now on.

4.- Lift the Z-axis to install the pen on the plotter. The tip of the pen should be below the tip of the extruder. You can see on the next images.

5.- Now put the paper where you want to draw. I put it on a clipped folder, which I attached to the bed of the printer. This allows you to change the sheets easily without having to calibrate at each occurrence.

6.- Low the Z-axis until the tip of the pen touch the paper. You must level the bed to make sure that the pen write fine on each zone of the paper. Use the same method that you use for level your printer.

7.- Note the height of the Z axis that your printer displays. We will use it to modify the Gcode. In my case i will use 15.91 mm, as you can see on the picture.

Then lift the Z-axis and prepare a new sheet for your drawing.

NOTE: Don't turn off the printer.

8.- Open the profile that I attached named "Texto.ini" on cura. It have the settings profile for use the wanhao like a plotter.

9.- Load the file that you want to draw. For this example I use the Shelby-logo that i attached. For best results your image must be on black&white.

10.- Cura will display a window named "Convert image", then put the follow values on each option:
Height: 0.2 mm
Base: 0 mm
and select "Darker is higher"

11.- Place the model on the desired position and the desired size.

12.- Save the Gcode file and open it on a Notepad program for edit it. I recommended NotePad++.

13.- Now the difficult part. If you have some experience on CNC code it must be more easy. First remember the Z position that you note on the step 7 (15.91 mm in my case), and add 2 or 3 mm. Then I going to use 15.91 mm and 17.91 mm, we need both.

14.- First you must change the line 37 "G1 Z20.0" for the second value "G1 Z17.91".

15.- Then erase the line 33 "G1 Z3.00".

16.- And modify the line 34 "G0 F3000 X62.318 Y51.358 Z0.200", you need to erase only the value of "Z0.200".

17.- Now press Ctrl+F and go to the option "Replace". On search put "Z0.200"and on replace put the first number, in my case "Z15.91". And click on replace all.

18.- Do the same with the next value: on Search put "Z3.200" and on replace put your second number, "Z17.91", and again click on replace all.

19.- Now scroll to the end of the code and check the line above the command "; END GCODE". In my case i have "G0 F3000 X107.091 Y159.770 Z5.200". You must erase the part "Z5.200". You can see on the images.

20.- Now you can save the Gcode file. Save it on the micro SD, put it on the printer and print the file. And it is all.

I attached the Gcode ("shelby-Logo_Original.gcode") original and the Gcode modified ("shelby-Logo_Modificado.gcode") so you can compared them. Both are on the zip file.

A better design for the X and Y axis strap pulleys.

This is a simple pulley I've made for the Prusa Mendel X and Y axis. 
You can fit a 688 bearing in it. Mount it with M8 bolts and nuts.

I loved the Arch iPad Stand made by walter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189730 But it didn't work with my iPad Air at all, and was not very stable with the iPad Mini either. I loaded it into my 3D app, modo ( http://www.thefoundry.co.uk/products/modo/ ), and crudely reshaped the hook to match the bezel and flatter back of the new iPad, Then I printed it and it worked. Thank you walter!

The first version I uploaded needed to be scaled up by a factor of 10. I have since replaced it with the correct version with dimensions 135.36mm x 90.47mm x 13.31mm  
I printed with 12% fill and 2 shells and .2mm layer height. No support or rafts necessary.

comments.text: Made this.  Works great for my old iPad.  I use it for a stand alone attendance and search station in my classroom.  Thanks!

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a more resin saving version of the Calibration Cube by iDig3Dprinting. It's made for SLA, DLP or LCD printers. It has the same size (20mm each side) and the axes are labeled for more convenience.

The bottom is open and drafted on the inside to allow good drain of the resin. Also there's a ventilation hole on the side as the top will normally be sitting on a print plate and not allow air to flow in.

title: Google Daydream Controller Emulator Cover for Galaxy S4

description.text:
This is a cover that clips on to a Samsung Galaxy S4 phone, when you want to use it as a Daydream controller emulator.

https://developers.google.com/vr/daydream/controller-emulator

The controller emulator software provides you with a virtual touchpad and virtual buttons on the screen of a secondary phone. Unfortunately, if you are actually using your phone in a headset for Daydream, you can't actually see the screen of this secondary phone; this makes it hard to find the outlines of the touchpad and buttons.

This clip-on case makes that somewhat easier. It also has little indented markers to distinguish the App button from the Home button, although really the position usually suffices for this.

description.text:
Replacement switch key for some older Craftsman power tools, in my case a 8" 620-1300-3100 Craftsman Drill Press. Replacement part number is a bandsaw switch key #60256 or craftsman switch key #22255. Usually a $6+shipping part if you can find them

Printed with PETG filament 20% infill, rotated so it was printed on its side with support for mechanical strength.

Mine was a little loose in the machine's switch, and could fall out after a few on-off cycles, but otherwise functional as a safety key

Printer:

Simple Black

Yes

20%

Notes:

Printed on its side with support added. Used PETG filament. Once support was removed easily fit into the switch key slot, and while it was a little loose, it was perfectly functional.

Used calipers to measure the broken part and modeled it in Autodesk Inventor 2016. Pins and rectangular shape was pretty basic work. The curve was based on some educated guess work. I make some measurements from flat portions to the curved button to estimate locations for a few points, placed those points in Inventor, then used a 3 point arc to find a best fit curve.

description.text: Mr_techie is the mascot icon created for a Helpdesk. My creation of this was in order to promote the Information Technology Services offered.

Aus irgendeinem Grund wollte ich meinen Mecreator2 auf Bowdenextruder umbauen. Dazu noch ein paar Gleitlager und gut.

Nach 5 Versuchen hat es dann endlich geklappt. Das große Problem dabei war der Gleitlagersitz.

  1. muss dazu der Drucker perfekt kalibriert sein und
  2. müssen die Gleitlager in Position "eingegossen" werden.

Das "Eingießen" habe ich mit 2K kleber aus der Mischerspritze realisiert. Die Lager kommen auf die Stangen und werden dann über die vorgedruckten Löcher im Gleiter mit 2K Kleber fixiert. Nicht zu viel, da sonst noch was auf die Stangen kommt... Hat bei mir aber auf Anhieb funktioniert.

Den original 40mm Lüfter vom Mecreator2 habe ich zum Fön umfunktioniert, was recht gute Ergebnisse liefert. Als Kühler vom E3DV6 habe ich den mitgelieferten 30mm Lüfter verbaut, der ganz nebenbei auch noch den Druckkopf selber kühlt. Dieser schmilzt jetzt nicht mehr
auf der Unterseite durch die aufsteigende Hitze vom Hotend. Dazu habe ich die Öffnung der Durchführung so designed, dass ähnlich einer Venturidüse ein Unterdruck entsteht und immer ausreichend Luft von unten angesaugt wird. Nicht zu viel und nicht zu wenig. Genau richtig.

Den Riemen habe ich mit den 2 Klemmen gespannt. Das funktioniert tadellos. Alles gedruckte Teile.

Die Vorteile eines Bowdenextruders sind eine geringere Masse - was zu einer starken Reduzierung des Ghostings führt und ein deutlich verbessertes Druckbild. Wirklich schneller kann ich jetzt zwar nicht drucken, aber die Oberflächen sind einfach besser geworden.

Achso... den Filamenthalter habe ich inzwischen auch nach hinten verlegt. Das bot sich einfach an.

Schreibt mal in die Kommentare, was ihr davon haltet.

description.text:
UPDATE: Depending on the servos you choose, they might overpower the nerdduino. BigLazyB used a 470uF capacitor across the nerduino's Vcc/Gnd to fix this issue.

Give your Chip-E what every biped deserves, a set of fully functional arms! This awesome upgrade greatly increases Chip-E's physical capabilities. With these two sexy arms, Chip-E can now do perfect push-ups, hardcore hammer curls, pick himself up off the ground, and much more!

Materials needed:
6x 9g 180° servos
4x M2x10 hex screws
4x M2 hex nuts
4x M3x15 male standoffs

The Chip-E hardware kit includes a bunch of spare parts, which includes extra M2x10 hex screws, M2 hex nuts, and M3x15 male standoffs.

A tip on the servos: I used these TowerPro servos in my Chip-E because they were so cheap, but I've had a lot of problems with them and a few broke quite easily, so I wouldn't recommend them unless you are on an extremely tight buget. Instead you might want to consider some metal gear servos like these.

Scroll down to the bottom for a cool animation!

Preset A contains all of the original Chip-E code.

Preset B has some new controls for the arms:

Button Function
UP Moves left arm up
DOWN Moves left arm down

SELECT Get down/do push-ups

A Moves right arm down

description.text:
A mashup of my Look of Disapproval Glasses, and the infamous Shutter Shades. The Shutter Shades of Disapproval basically combine my file ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19056 ) with that of Daewootech ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215 ) with some heavy modification. Iâ€™ve been playing with the design of the arms of the glasses. The original glasses had basic arms that you would just stick through holes, built into the frame. Sure, it worked, but it seemed to me like there was plenty of room for improvement.
The new glasses are designed to have the arms â€œgrabâ€ onto the glasses, with a slight â€˜snapâ€™ to it. Something that every engineer already knows: everything is a spring :) I may still refine the final clip, but I feel this is much better, and will even help prevent the arms from breaking, say if accidentally sat upon. Now the arms will just pop off the frames, instead of shattering everything.
JUST WANT TO PURCHASE A PAIR? You can still do that, over at my shop, The Plasmatorium: http://www.etsy.com/shop/Plasmatorium

These are meant to be cut out of 1/8in material. The snaps work well with acrylic.
I have not tested them with wood or MDF, but I would assume they would still work reasonably well on each.

title: Dressage Letters Stands
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Horse dressage requires arena to be marked with letters. This model is a simple and cheap way how to prop them on any soft surface.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

For single letter you need:

  • The letter itself, ie. printed on cardstock and laminated (use the DOCX or PDF files).
  • One Part A (DLS_PartB.stl) and one Part A (DLS_PartB.stl).
  • Four M4 x 12 socket cap screws.
  • Four M4 nuts.
  • Two M3 x 5 flat head screws (optional).
  • Two M3 nuts (optional).
  • One 180 x 6.0 nail.

Put the smooth surfaces of printed parts together and screw them lightly together with M4 screws and nuts. Place the big nail to hole in center and tighten the screws. Put the letter between the two parts. If you want to make them more sturdy, punch a hole into the sheet and use the M3 screws and nuts to hold the sheet in place.

Letters

There are DOCX and PDF files with letters available for printing and lamination.

I also included xx_12x8.studio3 files, intended for use with Silhouette cutting plotters. The files are intended fro 8x12" material, free space between letters is filled with horse silhouettes to use the foil that would be wasted otherwise.

A very simple filament guide for Fabrikator Mini II. Printed using PETG for additional tensile strength. Attached to the printer using existing screw (see the attached picture) and a bit of 3M double-sided tape for the curved part that hangs over the printer's edge. Easy to remove the filament from the guide thanks to the designed slot. Additionally you can fit most filament oilers between the guide and the extruder motor.
The guide feeds the filament slightly from top and behind of the extruder slot as I found it helps the extruder to feed better with faster printing speeds (more pre-tension for the teeth?).

Hi !
After 3 weeks, i'm proud to show you Budd-E, Chip-E's cousin, for the Remix challenge. This one can run next to you, look at you with his magnificent OLED eyes, raise his head, crouch, and most of all, DANCE !

Some printer will not be able to print some pieces of this robot without support, like the Chassis.

~200 grams of PLA filament 1.75mm
5 M3 x 1cm screws
2 pencil springs 4mm diameter
3 servo motor SG90 ( 2 of them will be definitely modificated )
2 OLED screen, 2.5 x 2.5cm modules.
4 DC motor 3 to 5V for arduino and smart car project
A Pololu DRV8835 motor driver
1 Lithium-ion cell 3.7V
1 Boost converter
1 Arduino Nano

I'm creating a step by step instruction, with all you need to get one ;)
all source code will be released soon

What's linking E.V.E. , Wall-E, R2D2 and BB-8 ? I made a list, and picked some features that i could add to Chip-E.

The robot need to have some "emotes", or something imitating feelings. For that, i replaced the original screen by 2 OLED, giving to Budd-E better face expressions. I added too a system for allow him to wobble, and crouch, increasing the number of dance move !
And, for allow him to have eyes contacts, i gave him a neck.

The robot need to have more mobility, so he is now capable to follow you, ( Originally, the robot was designed for running on a Raspberry PI Zero card, and use A camera to follow movements) thank to his large wheels

Pictures and videos taken during the developpement coming soon !

Notes:

I recommend scaling the model for FDM and cut off some of the base or remove it entirely as it doesn't scale well. You can print either the whole model or in pieces.

I prefer it in pieces with the arms at a 45-ish angle and the claws are pointing up, the torso I turn upside down so the armor pieces print pointing up as well. The head should be able to print flat but angle it as necessary.

For CURA and Slic3r: Using support interfaces really helps with improving the quality of prints printed at angles.

For CURA 6.2: enabling the gradient infill will help reduce material and number of top layers needed for a good finish. On models I like 4-6 with complex models but with a support set to 65% with 4-6 gradient steps 3-4 are fine.

Message = ENGAGEMENT

The factory cupholders on the 1992-1999 BMW 3-series (E36) are too narrow to be usable with modern cups. Cups don't sit level in the cupholders, causing the cup to tip over, making the cupholder unusable.

This conversion kit fixes that problem, and should fit any E36 including the 318i, 325i, 328i, and M3. It makes the cupholders shallower, but affords a flat surface for cups and cans to sit on.

You may want to print these parts in ABS to keep them from deforming on hot days. The insert has never deformed on me with PLA, but the ring has. It doesn't seem to bother the center console plastic if it deforms.

To install the parts:

  1. Pop the cupholder module out of the center console
  2. Remove the spring-loaded components from the cup holder
  3. Reinstall the cupholder module
  4. Install the insert and ring

title: Yet Another Fidget Spinner With Caps

description.text:
I designed my own spinner with Fusion 360 just for the learning experience.

Thanks to Joel the 3D Printing Nerd and Angus at Maker's Muse for their Fusion 360 tutorials that helped me get started in making this.

The caps interlock so they stay together better.

It uses 608 bearings. Clean the factory lube out of the bearings with alcohol and it will spin longer.

The caps fit really well when I use Matterhackers Pro PLA. I tried some blue Fillamentum and they fit too tight. You may need to make some adjustments to the extrusion multiplier or scale to get them to fit perfectly for your filament.

title: Spring Loaded CD Mount Tablet Holder

description.text:
Car CD mounted spring loaded adjustable tablet holder, should fit 4" to about 7" tablet.

Print orientation is as the pictures show.

Use a 1/4 x 20 x 1 1/2 in socket head bolt and a 1/4 x 20 nut for the knob.

The spring is a 3" tension type spring, that can be easily adjusted by stretching it, if needed,
the spring mounts between the two holes using whatever you want to use, I used some rivets I had lying around, trim as needed, I also used some CA on the pin to keep it from falling out.

This mount works great on a table top too.

title: Replacement Mailbox Door
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This mailbox door replacement was printed in PETG and then painted. The paint provides UV protection and makes it look good. The door does not have numbers but can be easily added if desired. I recommend using ether PETG or ABS. The door size is 8.25 in tall x 8 in wide x 1/4 in thick.

Mounting hardware:
-Two Spacer 1/4 inch diameter x 1/4 long.
-Two Pop Rivets 1/8 in. diameter x 3/8-1/2 in. Grip range ( which are about 3/4 in. long ).
-Ten Washers 1/8 inch .

Assembly instructions:
-Insert 1/4 inch spacers.
-Remove handle from old mailbox door and install in new door.
-Paint door.
-install new door in mailbox. I put washers everywhere, two on the outside, two on the inside and one on the inside between door and mailbox. Then crimp pop rivets and enjoy.

title: Duplicator 7 Big Big VAT
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi Guys This is my Take on a Big big Vat For those Longer and more Resin consuming Prints,i Have tested this many time over a month + and it Goes Good... Also I have one vat that I have Kept Resin in for a month without it leaking any Resin....You will need to use M4 Heat-Set Inserts for Plastics From McMaster-Carr

https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a353/=18fxv52

and Some M 4 Black-Oxide Alloy Steel Hex Drive Flat Head Screw

https://www.mcmaster.com/#91294a188/=18fxvhc

From them as well or any other Sellers that have the Same Specs items....

You can Modify the Tip of a regular Welding iron with a File to give it a Proper Shape to heat the Brass insert...

I Suggest Some test Piece to Practice first ,you don't want to scrap a Vat because you have no idea on how the insert will react when heated.

PS : You will need to readjust your Home Endstop Blade as the Vat is Much taller and will Contact the Plate Assembly Bracket before Switching on the Endstop and Also you will have to change the Screws to hold the Vat For same Thread but longer one, easy thing to do by removing the Cover at the Bottom and Removing the Screws and get the necc one at your local hardware store or Car shop since it is Metric ....

title: DJI Mavic Pro - Spring Loaded RC controller tablet mount.

description.text:
Spring loaded adjustable tablet or phone holder for use with the DJI Mavic Pro RC controller.

Use a 1/4 x 20 x 1 1/2 in socket head bolt and a 1/4 x 20 nut for the knob.

The print orientation is the same as the pictures.

The spring is a 3" tension type spring, that can be easily adjusted by stretching it, if needed,
the spring mounts between the two holes using whatever you want to use, I used some rivets I had lying around, trim as needed, I also used some CA on the pin to keep it from falling out.

This mount works great on a table top too.

description.text: This is a spinner that should be printed with 100% infill.

This is a triangle ring of the sort with a strap slot and a hole for clipping onto. It's customizable; this model is preset for a 2-inch strap, but you can customize it for other strap widths and thicknesses.

NOTE: Don't use this for anything where it could injure or kill someone if it breaks. I subjected my print to the “can I pull it apart with my bare hands” test and nothing more, and even then, your printer/filament may vary.

The distant colonies and trading depots have a wide variety of smaller gunship patrol ships, and this replica is one of the most common. Built with a combination of Federation engines with rudimentary laser turret and hull, designed and built by Icorre Group based on Epsilon Indi. The ships can be disassembled and placed in standard cargo containers and distributed to any star system, where the locals can re-assemble them quickly.
The ships are fast, but with limited range and no shields or other defenses. They are ideal ambush weapons which can fire and flee. The gun is a fairly standard nuke gun slug weapon but carries limited ammunition. This ship is designed to be a cheap defense asset, but unless used in numbers, they cannot stand up to even a single Alien Meson gunship.
In service, despite being known as "5 minute ships" by their crews, they have proved cheap and useful.

title: Drag chain ends for "cablemonkey" (Amazon) Medium 0.75"x0.5" cable track

description.text:
I bought a couple sections of 0.75"x0.5" (inner) drag chain from Amazon from https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01L0CQ6IQ.

The system is designed not to need end links, but I prefer the look and how the cable routes with end links.

Both print on my printer (wanhao i3 plus) without supports, but if your printer doesn't like overhangs, support is advisable. I used 10% infill, but if your layers aren't strong you may want to bump it up.

FYI: Holes are 5mm diameter 16mm apart

description.text:
A storage box to store all the specialty ship tokens for Nemo's War 2nd Edition by Victory Point Games. Holds all the different colored ship tokens that can come into play during the course of a game. I got tired of throwing all the ships into the same bag between games :)

UPDATE: You may want to use the newer files with the word "Large" at the end. The version I originally uploaded was maybe a bit too snug. Also included a plain lid without the logo for this larger version.

Box contains slots for:
7x Red Ships
4x Orange Ships
4x Dark Yellow Ships
4x Blue Ships
4x Green Ships
2x Black Ships

The logo on the lid could use a little work I think!

comments.text: I like it!  The large box fits like a glove.  Well done!
comments.author: Cnpeters

title: Flame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Turn up the heat with this ogo flame! Add some fire power to thrusters, give some spikey hair to your bald characters, use it as a pointy tree!  
The OGOBILD attachments are interchangeable, safe, and functional toys you can use to create anything you can imagine. Now you can download, modify, and print out your own custom pieces.
You can print at a low resolution with a raft and supports.

comments.text: Oh my! I've just discovered your ogo things. They are really fun. I'll be printing a lot of them. There's a soon to be three year old that's going to think I've gone crazy...er. If he doesn't have a lot of fun with these at least I will. :)
comments.author: Arvin

comments.text: Hi Arvin! I'm glad you're excited about our stuff. I would recommend starting out with the short and bent ball posts as well as the 2 ball/2 socket and 2 socket joints. They are the essential pieces to build things. You can use the other pieces to add a little flair to what you build. You can check out http://bits.ogosport.com/http://bits.ogosport.com/ to get some ideas of what pieces you'll need to make characters.

description.text:
Simple relay standoff mount.

Module is here:
Gikfun 2 Channel 5V Relay Shield Module for Arduino UNO 2560 1280 ARM PIC AVR STM32 Raspberry Pi EK1156

If you like my designs why not tip me a dollar or two. Your support will allow me to spend more time on these designs and their variations. Thanks!

comments.text: I like the idea, but something about the way the 4 standoffs are modeled really throws Slic3r for a loop, causing it to skip printing anything on certain layers under those standoffs, which pretty quickly ends up making a big mess out of it.  In the STL it almost looks like the standoffs are separate pieces rather than all one integral body.
comments.author: funkenjaeger

title: logitech c920 Lack leg camera holder

description.text:
pocket holds the cam for easy install/removal.

print and twist to free the hinge, slide/screw a m3 screw for an axel (im using a short one that only reaches half way and it holds fine no need for anything crazy or having to go get a custom size)

comments.text: I originally printed a magnetic version which was designed to mount to the printer itself however after reading up on the magnets can cause issues with the stepper motors I reconsidered my options and came across your model. It printed beautifully without any supports and as I have no M3 screws I just stuck a toothpick in the hole. Working fine and is nice to have the webcam away from the printer as to get a better view of the entire print bed.
comments.author: PixelBay

description.text:
Found this thing here https://free3d.com/3d-model/volcanion-pokemon-55191.html
It was not made for 3D printing, I tossed it though some tools and made it 3D print ready. I also posed him a bit. You'll need supports. If anyone knows how I should set the license, please let me know.

Warning, there are intersecting surfaces in this model, refer to your slicer on how to best handle them. For S3D, I selected the model and chose "mesh"->"separate connected surfaces" and then in the process under "advanced" I turned on "merge all outlines into a single model"

description.text:
I've been using this PLA filter, but why settle for a boring cylinder?

There is a slot in the bottom where you can insert a piece of sponge that has a light coating oil. Almost any cooking oil can work, but I'd check to make sure the smoke point of the oil is higher than the printing temperature. (Olive oil has a smoke point of 210C, refined safflower oil is 266C.)

This started in about April of 2017 when I realized that I had no real place to put my Super Scope. So my idea was to just mount it to the wall so that it can be on display kind of like how a firearm would be. This was the end result, complete with the stylish Super Famicom logo.

Hope this solution helps you display one of the cooler things that was made for the Super Nintendo.

This is a Runcam Split mount for the Armattan Chameleon. It uses the standard holes that come in the stock Chameleon camera mounting plates. It also incorporates a captive nut slot to use the stock tilt adjustment screws. This works best with the 2.5mm lens, pushing it right up to the edge of the frame. At around 30 degrees, there is only a small bit of props visible in the bottom corners of the HD video.

Print this in TPU with supports. You will need a non-locking m3 nut for the tilt adjustment thumb screw. I had to trim the m2 screws that are used to mount the camera so they would not bottom out in the case. There is just enough clearance for the mounting screws, while providing a secure and adjustable mount.

For more FPV and quad stuff, check out my other things and blog over at http://fpvobsession.com/.

UPDATES:

  • Added a version that should work well for the shorter lens. I have not printed this as I don't have the short lens to test. Please let me know how it works and I can adjust if necessary.

title: Anycubic I3 Mega Open Hotend Cover

description.text:
I found the standard i3Mega hotend cover annoying, either because it necessarily limited my view of the nozzle, or because it was tedious to remove and replace, or because I wanted to access the connectors, or just because it being black constantly messed with my camera's auto-exposure.
Also, it is no longer forced to blow all of the air coming off the heatsink down onto the print, so in theory your nozzle fan may be more effective now.
This is a cut-down remix of
http://thingiverse.com/thing:2376385

2017-09-26
Added *-005.stl according to comment recommendation:

  • Holes are now all 3.4mm in diameter, for use with the same M3 bolts and a 0.4mm nozzle but without needing to drill them out (yeah, I got tired of doing that a while ago too).
  • The nut holes are now tighter. You will need to heat the nut over a flame for a second or two prior to pressing it into the slot. If you have never done this before just start slow, and remove the nut as soon as you see it wasn't hot enough and you aren't going to get it in, then reheat more and retry. It's pretty simple and very worth learning. Make sure the bolt hole in the print lines up with the nut you are inserting to know when it's been inserted the right distance.
    That said: it's possible the nuts can be inserted just by application of a little force, so try that first. Your specific nut and print tolerances will determine if it works or not. Even if they do fit, melting them in slightly keeps them in place.
  • I only updated the most recent version with the big hex-holes/thin hex structure. All other files are unchanged.

2017-07-26
Added:
-002 to 004.stl
slapped in some fan protection. Because several weeks have passed and I don't hate the first one, but it is far too easy to put fingers in the fan.

2017-07-11
Original file:
*-001.stl

description.text:
This could easily be changed at any time, as I may need to tweek it depending on how long this one lasts
I got a DJI Spark a week ago and have been using my nexus 5x with the controller. I have a Nexus 7 tablet I rarely use but it doesnt fit in the spark controller arms. So I modeled up a fake Nexus size block and two posts with a bracket on top that fits the Nexus 7 well....Note, I added 2% to the print in slicing to make up for some shrinkage and it was spot on.
I printed it today and just used it tonight. I had some screws laying around..3/4" #4 (sheet metal or wood screws are fine), with counter sunk heads. Used a counter sink bit to the printed holes to make them fit just right on the top and bottom pieces. 4 screws total. Printed in PETG.

author: Entropy2

description.text:
https://youtu.be/xnNJ8LDQF4Y

This CHIP-E can balance on two wheels, just like a segway or hoverboard.

This is the Chip-E robot with a modified bottom plate to accommodate 2 micro-metal gear motors with their brackets.
The new bottom plate was designed with Autodesk Fusion 360.

To build this robot I printed the original Chip-E parts (except for the bottom plate).
Besides the basic Chip-E kit, I used:

  • A pair of Pololu's micro-metal gear motors (150:1), with their respective brackets for mounting
  • A pair of 70x8mm wheels for the motors.
  • One MPU6050 IMU sensor (mounted on Head)
  • One TB6612FNG motor driver.

Connections from Arduino to MPU6050:
GND <-> GND
5V <-> VCC
PIN A4 <-> SDA
PIN A5 <-> SCL
PIN 2 <-> INT

Connections from Arduino to TB6612FNG
5V <-> VCC
5V <-> STBY
PIN 6 <-> AIN1
PIN 7 <-> AIN2
PIN 10 <-> PWMA
PIN 8 <-> BIN1
PIN 9 <-> BIN2
PIN 11 <-> PWMB

Download code here: http://femb.com.mx/files/CHIP_E_BALANCE.rar

remixed_from.author: neuport
remixed_from.title: Hex Tile Holders such as for JAWong 3D Catan Terrain Pieces

title: Magnetic base for JAWONG Catan tiles

description.text: I designed this base when I saw JAWONG's Catan tiles several months ago. This base holds 6 small, cylindrical, diametrically polarized magnets. The magnets are free to rotate about their axes. With the base glued to the bottom of the tiles, the tiles are self assembling and hold together. I made a few for testing using these magnets (cyl0065D http://www.supermagnetman.net/index.php?cPath=30) and they worked fantastically. However, the magnets were too expensive for an entire set and I ended up using the snap together borders instead which also have the port holders.

The tile is oriented upside down for printing so that the top surface, which is printed on the build platform, is as smooth as possible to make a perfect glue joint with the smooth bottom of the tiles.  
A medium or thick cyanoacrylate adhesive works well for attaching the bases.  Load the magnets, put a few drops of glue (away from the magnet wells) and then press on the tile.  
The glue fixture aids in aligning the tiles.  It would work better if the alignment tabs were at the corners.

comments.text: The thing with the tabs is a glue fixture as explained in the instructions.  It was meant to help align the tile with the magnetic base when gluing.  If you're careful you probably don't need it.  As noted in the instructions, it would have work better if the tabs were placed at the vertices rather than the middle of the sides.  Hope this helps.
comments.author: neuport

comments.text: Does the Catan tile snap into the part with the tabs on, or does the Catan tile get glued on top of the piece with the holes in? If the latter, I don't see what the piece with the tabs on is for.
comments.author: kellogg76

comments.text: The magnets I linked in the description drop into the 6 slots.  They are diametrically magnetized cylinders and lie on their sides in the bottom of the slots.  They should fit loosely so that they can rotate around their long axes.  The Catan tile is then glued on top, trapping the magnets in the base.  Be careful not to get glue in the slots, the magnets must be free to rotate.  That way, when two tiles are brought together, the magnets will rotate into N/S alignment and snap the tiles together.
comments.author: neuport

comments.text: Hi, thank you for this sharing. I'm a little confused about placing magnets. Can you show how to load magnets to hexagons? I couldn't understand instructions well. Thank you!
comments.author: baronmortis

remixed_from.author: IdefixRC
remixed_from.title: Mini Differential IR Probe mount for Replicator 2X

description.text:
This is part 1 of the Replicator 2/2X DuetWifi Upgrade series.
Part 2,3 and 4 can be found here:

  • Part 1: DuetWifi Installation and PanelDue Mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2428995)
  • Part 2: Mini Differential IR Probe mount for Replicator 2X (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2475179)
  • Part 3: DuetWifi Configuration files for Replicator 2X (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2475257)
  • Part 4: Simplify3D Slicer Configuration for the Replicator 2X (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476695)

My Makerbot Replicators 2x has served me well for many many years. Finally something broke down and it started to reset itself mid print. As replacing all the cables in the machine did not fix the problem I suspected a mainboard or PSU problem. Long story short: it was time for an upgrade.

The new Replicator 2X now runs a Duetwifi board with reprap firmware, utilizes a IR sensor to measure the bed height and provide mesh bed leveling and displays all the data on a 5'' color touch screen mounted at the same place the old Makerbot display was positioned.

What do you need for the conversion?

  • 1x Duetwifi Mainboard - http://www.reprap.me/duetwifi-electronics-board.html
  • 1x PanelDue 5'' Display - http://www.reprap.me/paneldue-with-5-screen-for-duetwifi.html
  • 2x M3 Thermistor - http://www.reprap.me/m3-modular-screw-on-stud-thermistor-hot-end-screw-type-thermistors-for-3d-printer.html
  • 1x 24V PSU - http://www.reprap.me/power-supply-24v-15a.html
  • connectors or cables in case you want to keep your Replicator 2/2x stock cable set for the future.

Connection:

  • Extruder heaters, fans, extruder thermostor, heated bed and bed thermistor connection is straight forward
  • Steppers connection is straight forward as well. Simply connect the wires to the board in the same order as you see them on the stepper motor - minus the gap between the pins)
  • Endstop connection is done by combining the center 2 pins (these are the ground pins) from the Makerbot endstops to the gnd pin on the Duetwifi 3pin connector. signal and VCC according to the markings on the endstop and duetwifi mainboard
  • Now you can drive the Zaxis homing either with the stock endstop or use a probe sensor such as the IR probe for duetwifi by DC42 (http://www.reprap.me/ir-probe-for-duetwifi.html)

I mounted the board with stand-off to the bottom of the printer in-between the stock makerbot standoffs.4 holes are required in the bottom of the printer for that (M3). I also mounted the PSU beside it at the bottom to get a nice compact installation. There is enough space between PSU and bottom of the printer to allow the cooling fan to ventilate the PSU

You can even hook the LED up to a spare fan connector on the board (plus minus leads only) for it to shine red while in operation.

Last remove the old Display and mount the PanelDue.
The attached STL is a modification of the enclosure made by DC42. It has a few slots to allow you to store SD cards (if you want to use the SD Card slot in the paneldue, you need to purchase a 10pin ribbon cable to hock it up to the mainboard).
Install the panel and mount the enclosure to the front using M3 screws (Countersink recommended)

Finally configure your printer with the reprap configurator.
Please visit Part 2 for the IR Sensor mount and Part 3 for the Duetwifi configuration files (dual extruder).

Enjoy your new, wifi connected, Replicator printer :-)

MakerBot

description.text:
I have a shallow desk depth and didn't like how my CH Pro Pedals have their cable coming straight out of the back where it gets pressed against the wall. Two of these little feet will protect the cable and the wall.

The spacers are attached to the pedals with 1" double-stick tape and it seems to be holding strong even after some abuse. I added little rubber feet to the indentations on back of the spacer but I don't think they are strictly required and mine keep falling off anyway.

Version 2 will have some provision for routing the USB cable through the feet.

remixed_from.title: Print PLA with Makerbot Replicator 2x Upgrade

title: Replicator 2x Flexion Extruder Part Cooling Fan

description.text:
After upgrading my extruders to flexion extruders and hotends and installing a IR bed probe to the extruder carriage (see Duetwifi conversion here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2428995) I modified the excelent cooling fan mounts from 3dprintler which I did use with my old setup before to fit the new setup.

This required integrating standoffs between extruder fans and cooling shrouds as well as reducing the outlet height as the flexion hotends are a bit shorter then my old hotends.

Best print in ABS, solid with no raft or support (the file has integrated supports at the opening closest to the hotend which needs to be removed after printing).

Visit 3dprintler's thing page for info on the fans required (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221306).
For my installation I combined 2 fans on one of the duetwifi's PWM fan connectors and control the via the slicer depending on layer height, print speed and status (e.g. bridging) for PLA and ABS prints (has improved the ABS print details significantly).

title: Rubbing Templates for drawing (e.g. owl, seahorse, spider, crab)

description.text:
These rubbing templates are great for a child to place underneath a piece of paper and then rub with a pencil or crayon... instant coloring book!

These are 1.75mm thick, with a 1mm base and .75mm ridges; I print them at .25 layer height and they look great; no need for very thin layer heights with these objects.

Print them in two colors to make great wall decorations. In this case, configure a color change at 1.25mm so the ridges are different color than the baseplate. Then use blue-tack or earthquake putty to put right on a wall.

The icons are Creative Commons licensed from The Noun Project, a great resource for high quality royalty free and/or Creative Commons icons: https://thenounproject.com

title: Hinged Dust Cover for 16mm CB/Aviation Connector

description.text:
I made some hinged "dust covers" for a project.

I like to use what are commonly called CB or Aviation plug connectors for stepper motor connectors.

They are inexpensive, easy to connect and carry a decent amount of current. Most importantly, the opening is keyed so the connector won't spin when inserting and removing the plug.

You can find the connectors on amazon at https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-10Pairs-Thread-Aviation-Connector/dp/B016FCZ5SS

This cover fits the common 16mm thread connectors (e.g. 3-pin, 4-pin, 5-pin and 6-pin) I haven't tried larger pin count connectors, but if its 16mm, I'm pretty sure it'll work.

Snap the two parts together with some care and they'll stay in place. I put some mild camming on the lid so it'll stay at 90 degrees even if you install the unit so the lid closes down with gravity.

Designed to print with no supports at any resolution that works for your printer. Remember to flip the lid over 180 degrees (I saved as STL directly from the assembly in fusion 360 and it kept orientation)

title: MPSM V2 fan shroud with blow ring

description.text:
I wanted a fan shroud with better part cooling, and couldn't find one that fit what I was looking for, so I pulled out a ruler, opened OpenSCAD, and started designing!

The original stl and ver2 stl are for the stock 30mm fan. There are a 30mm and 40mm variant of the ver3 version which rounds off corners and cleaned up some areas that bugged me.

The ver2 files have a redesigned ring and can now print in a right-side-up orientation, and should be fine with no support.

The ver3 files have the corners rounded off on the fan mount, and better supports 40mm fans. The 30mm variant should still print with no supports, but the overhang on the back for the 40mm variant will work better with supports.

This is still a work in progress and files will be updated as I make changes.

title: Velomobile Aero Shell for B&M; Cyclestar Mirror

description.text:
This is a shell and custom stem for a B&M Cyclestar mirror. The ball end of the stem inserts into the mirror socket. The straight end inserts into the top hole/boss in the shell. The stem has been left long so you can cut to the length to fit the mirror in the shell where you like it. The hole in that top boss has been left a bit small so you can drill to get a tight fit for the stem. The shell is attached to the velomobile with one or two 5mm bolts and nuts through the base.

This mirror shell looks a bit funky straight off the printer. I'd suggest sanding and painting them.

I've printed these in PLA. If they crack, I'll switch to ABS or nylon. The stem should be printed horizontally in nylon for strength.

One last thing... My printer may not be calibrated perfectly so you may have to tweak the dimensions a bit.

description.text:
I created this in an attempt to fit a beer tap handle that I will add shortly. Most tap handles i found used a 3/8 16 threading, but I needed 1/2 20.

So I measured it and the interior diameter was 8mm. I tried an 8mm threaded rod and it was just slightly too small. So 9 mm seemed the way to go. You can use it as a hole and design your own beer tap, or as the screw if you need a 9mm Bolt.

comments.author: garym57

description.text:
I redid the design from scratch. Improvements include:

  • requires no drilling of new holes, attaches to motor mount screws (you will need longer screws to attach the motor mounts).
  • slightly thicker for more stability
  • more triangles to improve stiffness
  • 3 tiewraps per rod instead of 2. Also go higher up the rods.

There is a calibration piece because my own printer is not very accurate in scale and it is important that the parts fits snugly to the rods. If you need to tweak scale print the calibration piece first until it fits.

comments.text:
Cool, have you noticed any improvement after installing it?
I'm finishing a friend's rostock (it was laying around in his house for a year).
Also, what do you think about removing the need for the zip ties and using a second part tha screws together holding everything up? It might add some more stiffness, I guess.
comments.author: mballoni

comments.text: I have the qualitative feeling that it can now print faster without causing problems, but I am still working on a qualitative assessment of the vibrations with and without using an accelerometer.
comments.author: mballoni

comments.text:
Sure!!! If thats not a problem for you I would love to print a second part and certainly will give you some feedback (along with some pictures).
I'm fixing a rostock that a friend stopped working on last year and we plan on donating it to a NGO that prints prothesis so I'm looking for some improvements I can make before it finishes.

Robot educativo DYOR para secundaria de bajo coste para iniciarse en la robótica. Es de fácil construcción y permite gran variedad de experimentos como evitar obstáculos,melodías,siguelíneas,pantalla leds y bluetooth para controlarlo remotamente
Muy fácil de decorar con goma eva u otros materiales

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4ZEEfA6Wy4O

Para más información: Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

Software:
Tinkercad (diseño del robot y piezas) ,Plantilla corte con laser , Fritzing ( conexiones electrónicas), Facilino 1.0.1 (compatible arduino) y App inventor 2

Hardware:
Chasis de madera de 150mmx150mm
Electrónica: Arduino nano v3.0(compatible), extensión arduino nano, sensor ultrasonidos(HC-SR04),zumbador KY-006, matrix de leds 8x8 max7219,spp-c bluetooth(compatible HC-06), siguilíneas TCRT-5000,2 microservos de rotación continua con ruedas FS-90R , 2 microservos SG-90, rueda loca y bateria Powerbank 2000 mAh.

Chasis del robot es de madera cortado con láser.
Decoración realizada con goma eva. Se necesita pegamento de barra o cola blanca.

I have my 3d printer only for a few weeks now.
This is one of my first designs.
Newbie at work :-)

Windchimes dupont wires holder.

Dupont wires can create a mess, a labyrinth of many many wires.
Try to find the right wires you want, among hundreds of wires.

This Dupont Wires Holder makes it easier to find the right dupont wire.

The wires can be sorted on pin combination, pin-pin, pin-bus, bus-bus.
And can be sorted on color.

There are parts to make holders for 10 cm, 20 cm and 30 cm dupont wires.

FREECAD file included.

To solve this I recently glued the parts together.
Much more stable :-)
